It's time to play The Puzzle.
He's puzzle editor of The New York Times and WEEKEND EDITION's puzzlemaster.
Last week's challenge, what was it?
Well, it came from listener Matt Pillai (ph) of Denver.
I said think of a common five-letter word.
If you insert an E after the second letter, you'll get a common six-letter word.
If instead you insert an E after the fourth letter, you get another six-letter word.
And if instead you insert an E at the end, you'll get still another six-letter word.
And the word is spars - S-P-A-R-S.
Do those E's, you get spears, spares and sparse.
We received 382 responses, and the winner this week is Jacob Jaffe of Seattle, Wash.
We are still continuing with the West Coast for the win.
Jacob, how did you figure out this week's challenge?
Well, I thought the five-letter word was probably plural, that an E could go before or after the S.
And then I thought of six-letter words that end in S-E, and I came up with sparse.
And what do you do for a living?
I'm about to start my first year of teaching.
All right, and how long have you been playing The Puzzle?
Oh, you came to us new.
Every answer today is the name of a famous person with only one name, either because they literally had only one name or because they're generally known by one name.
I'll give you anagrams, you name the people.
For example, if I said usual - U-S-U-A-L - minus U for a biblical king, you would say Saul.
No. 1 is video - V-I-D-E-O - minus E for a Roman poet.
No. 2 is chrome - C-H-R-O-M-E - minus C, Greek poet.
Leader - L-E-A-D-E-R - minus R, a singer.
Shaken - S-H-A-K-E-N - minus N, another singer.
I keep looking for Cher, but it's not Cher.
I keep on wanting to bust out in song, and you're taking away my moment.
Titanic - T-I-T-A-N-I-C - minus C, an Italian artist.
Pearlash - P-E-A-R-L-A-S-H - minus S, a painter.
Optician - O-P-T-I-C-I-A-N - minus I, a Native American leader.

Oh, bygone car - Opticon - no, that's not - Pontiac.
